Not enough time in the day for reading? Think again.

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Nov 24, 2015

23 to 29 November 2015 is Book Week Scotland – Scotland’s annual celebration of books & reading. They have some really interesting stuff going on – and just because we are south of the border doesn’t mean we can’t get involved!

Read Instead – Find some time to read during the day.

Think you don’t have time for reading? Think again! Book Week Scotland have devised a cunning test will reveal how much extra reading time you can find in the day. Now, I read for pleasure every day (normally at least an hour before bed). I took the challenge and got some surprising results.

How it works – first I entered the average times I spend doing the following activities on an average day.

I hit the calculate button to find out what extra reading I could be squeezing in. I got the following…

By faffing on my phone and watching the dreary adverts on 4oD during Peep Show I am missing out annually on five and a half million words a year! And how did it know that I am yet to tackle the The Odyssey…

The test is only a bit of fun but it could be a great eye-opener for proving to someone that they do indeed have time to read. I loved that the results even give you book titles it thinks you could read. The recommendations are genuinely different every time so why not give it a try yourself. Teachers – you could use it during an assembly to raise awareness.

Journeys: Get the Book!

There is also a free eBook to download with stories based around taking a journey. I have downloaded a copy already and intend to read as many of the collected stories as I can in all the spare time created using the test above…

Intrepid storytellers from across Scotland share the journeys that mean the most to them – whether that’s a trip around the world or a visit to a precious moment in the past. Leave your suitcase at home, let your imagination do the travelling for you and dip into tales of stunning landscapes, misadventures, relocations and relationships.

With stories from the Scottish public plus well-known writers including Andrew O’Hagan, Jenni Fagan and Lucy Ribchester, this is a book that will take you places.

Happy Book Week Scotland – and well done for some great reading ideas.

    About

    My name is Matt Shenton and I am working for Suffolk Libraries as a dedicated ‘Literacy Ambassador’ for the next year. My role is to work with schools, statutory and voluntary organisations and other interested parties to promote reading for pleasure and the importance of literacy to young people and their families in Suffolk.
